headline.main: Council Members Buttonhole One Another on Pet Projects

docs.abstract: Members of New York City Council seeks support from one another for their pet projects in negotiations with mayor's office over budget; vie to show each other and constituents how effective they are (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: As budget negotiations between the two sides of City Hall sputter along, council members have busied themselves in a parallel process of wheedling and cajoling one another to stand firm on restoring favored services to the city's spending plan. Like the lobbyists who crowded the City Hall patio so tightly that they were roped off from the entrance yesterday, council members have been inundating one another with phone calls, faxes and fliers -- all in an effort to solidify support for their often competing causes. Although a few members have always operated like internal organizers, officials and experts say, that quotient has greatly expanded this year with the sudden influx of 38 new members.

headline.main: It Could Be the Air: Westchester Registers High Smog Levels

docs.abstract: Article on high smog levels in Westchester County, NY, which has failed American Lung Assn's nationwide test of air quality based on measures of ground-level ozone levels from 1998 through 2000; much of county's ozone pollution comes from coal-fired power plants, both near and far, and car and truck emissions; link between childhood asthma and high smogs levels discussed; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S official: Westchester County has terrible air. The American Lung Association announced last month that Westchester County failed a nationwide test of air quality, based on measures of ozone levels gathered over three years, from 1998 through 2000. Among the 26 counties tested in New York State, Westchester ranked seventh worst for dangerously high smog levels, behind counties in New York City and Suffolk, Putnam, Chatauqua and Erie Counties, according to the Association's State of the Air 2002 report.
